title: Semantics 2014
segmentation: Good, I'm going to break the rules right away.
I'm not going to talk about semantics and I'm I don't have three slides.
I got more give you a little bit of background.
I'm leaving here to go to Paris to a meeting that in principle is setting information technology, road map for ICT, for Europe, for the next decade.
So it's something called airsim.
It's the Association of all the National Science Foundations of all the European Union countries.
I've done a lot of Rd mapping over my time and so I think the story I'm going to argue here is precisely what Richard said yesterday at Telefonica about Telefonica.
An what Mark said about the semantic technology, namely find a problem.
So I'm just going to emphasize that.
I have it's a bit of a joke I'm on and I'm on so many advisory boards, but I have been until this year on the Advisory Board of Forrester Research and previous to that.
I was on Gartner's Advisory Board.
And I tried to lobby both of them to add semantics to their.
Analysts, one of the main topics they cover into their analyst coverage and Gartner was very happy to comply and they they put taxonomy people on.
Not technology, not semantic people at all, so there's a modest, very modest amount of coverage in force during Gardner.

So the message here related to what John said yesterday about taking the message to those different programs is you've got to get in the door somehow, and semantics the story of semantics isn't widely.
Accepted.
So there are problem owners and they have problems to be solved and those are the people you need to serve.
And then there's the technology.
So what's going to happen in 2014?
I think social networks will be a platform for many applications.
One example will be virtual worlds.
That sounds like games, right?
Not at all.
The biggest, most powerful, biggest market in what are called virtual worlds nowadays.
It's called the High performance workplace.
IBM is the market leader on it.
Basically, when you go to work, you sit at A at a desk and that desk selects for you all the services and things that you need to do your job.
It's tailored for you, you can tailor it, but the high performance work twice as an extremely growing industry.
The reason being is it increases productivity.
The benchmark when IBM scented set into this was people knowledge workers spend 60% of their time looking for information and less than 40% of the time working on their job.
So the premise of the high productivity workplace is and it's starting in virtual worlds.
You want to prevent presented world to them that is very common to them.
An Google who gives a hoot about Google.
You have a means for searching your documents or their pre search for you.
Ecosystems, so nowadays we talk about big applications.
We know about ERP by 2014.
I'm pretty sure there will.
You will be thinking entirely of end to end ecosystems that you participate in to execute your job.
That is the going to be part of a system.
Look for where semantics can take leverage in any one of these domains, in technology or in the solution domain, cloud computing is going to be big.
Unified Communications is going to be big.

Unified Communications is not unlike what's being spoken about in the future Internet, namely, all of your communication modes, whether it's telephone, computer, I am your refrigerator, whatever it is, they're going to be all organized in a simple, unified way.
This ideas.
From 1970, by the way, Everything is going to be automated.
And the scale is going to be billions of platforms that need to interoperate and give you a sense of the size of the of the web and.
Traffic on the web.
I have another slide here to show you that as a yottabyte.
Actually, an exabyte is the video recordings of all the meetings that ever took place last year across the entire world.
1000 of those is as a debate and the data end.
The web grows bigger than a Zeta bite a year, and they've estimated 44266 data bytes per month.
Go.
Is traffic across the web so things?
Just just a sense to say that it's big.
So the scenario for roadmapping that I have always part.
Well when I was younger we didn't do this, but now I'm older we do.
Is you search for problem domains, whether it's social computing, whether it's business optimization, whether it's supply chain, whatever it is.
You first of all search for this problems.
By the way, does this look familiar?
This is precisely what Telefonica did.
Andrew DI think?
Rudy told me, this is precisely what IBM does.
So to do professional Rd mapping, you don't say we're going to have the greatest widget you ever saw and everybody is going to love it.
You're going to say we're going to solve the X problem, the finding the document I need problem.
So you go from problems to solutions.
Try to find out what kind of solutions could fit the problem space and guess what.
A solution involves far more than just semantics.
Semantics is unlikely to be the key player in any one of these solutions.
It's likely to be something else, but semantics is probably going to be an enabler.
Then you look at the technology space, the emerging technology space, or the existing technology space, and you try to map the solutions.
Onto technologies then you come to your road map.
So I have now some eye charts.
I don't intend you to read them.
But I think it's what you call it.
A humbling experience.
These are hype charts from Gartner I. I just had them on my machine last night, so I just took them.
There's there's.
There's a technology wave charts from Forrester.
There's Magic Quadrant from Gartner.
Every organization has their own, but just to show you an emerging technologies overall, I tried to find any one technology that had a semantic component.
And the closest I could come with social computing platforms and social network analysis are these.
Those inherently semantic, not necessarily.

So the basic argument of this entire presentation is find where there is a technology that doesn't fully address the problem you know is going to exist and that semantic technology would be the enabler of that technology.
So part of these slides is those these are the guys on the rise in the fall, and where can you find a niche to add technology?
Semantic technology that would make them more able to solve the problems that you've previously find as being important.
So just a few more databases.
Data integration.
I've spent my entire career on databases and data integration.
Do you see semantics in any one of these things?
Master Data Management is this marketing ploy put out by IBM ASAP, Oracle and the others?
And they say if you have the concept of an employee, we will allow.
We will provide technology that facilitates the integration of all of your employee related data.
So for Rudy we will find in your enterprise all Rudy information and make it collected into one place.
We can manage it.
I'll tell you, nobody knows how to do it.
Even with the product's, so it's incredibly.
It doesn't seem like a normal play for.
Antics to be added.
Social software, even within social software.
You can't find a single emerging technology that really has a core semantic.
Opponent.
Business process management are huge and increasingly important domain.
Again rule based management systems.
So this is some semantics there.
But rule based systems have been around since the 80s.
So not much place their consumer technology is not a single mention of anything semantic.

One would think that personal, personal identification, personal preferences, anything that would allow me to automatically interact with my digital world in a way that it understood me would be absolutely crucial here.
It's not even mentioned.
Then the final one enterprise communication technologies speech recognition.
That's the only thing I could.
Find there was related, so this is the way that I'm not purporting.
We do this, but this is the way that Gartner does it.
They talk about the benefits as to whether you know they just solve a little problem or whether they're going to transform the industry and they do it over periods of years as well.
So that's another way to set the frame for what's happening.
So.
Let me tell you a story I got into this semantic technology domain some years ago, largely at the invitation of Detar.
I was giving a talk a keynote somewhere on integration and he thought, wow, that's exactly where semantics is going to work or can work and so he and I sat down.
He and I.
About twelve others sat down and wrote a paper.
Seasons semantically enabled service orientation or something like that.
And the premise was.
Due to the scale of the service oriented world, one would need something like semantic.
Some increased automation to facilitate identifying.
Searching, selecting, negotiating, integrating, composing services.
So this is up five or six years later.
Has any semantic technology solutions been adopted in that area?
I think not.
If you look at the commercial vendors not at all.
Hasn't made an impact, Oracle has within its just occur to me.
Oracle just bought Bea.
Oracle was working on a repository, what's called a repository registry or repository.
Registry is like the old CORBA idea of a broker.
That is to say, you declare to the broker all the services you have.
And if you need a service, you request the service.
And it'll go to the broken certain.
Well, yeah, we got what you need.
Will send it to you and then quit.
The issue.
Is there matching by the way I made a mistake.
We have a very large SOA in Verizon and I thought the scale was the issue.
I've got the wrong word scale.
I meant up there I had I.
We thought, you know, in order to find one out of millions, the issue was that's where you'd need semantics.
But guess what?
Defined one you need semantics because we built our SOA to be one of the largest in the world and we had immense trouble with reuse.
Reuse is the principle of SOA, right?
You want to reuse the service.
And so even finding one match.
Let alone say seven or eight.

I don't mind if I were able to show an employee seven matches that were close matches because it didn't find the exact unique one that's far better than not being able to find many or having browse manually.

So after so there's a huge value proposition there, but nobody in industry has taken it on, so this organization in its previous days was based on the premise that SOA is going to require semantics and the industry simply hasn't.
It's what we call the 0 billion.
Dollar market.
So find the problems were semantic technology the end?
The end problems, the social networking, virtual worlds, whatever it happens to be.
Where social semantic technology can provide leverage when you go down to the solution domain.
When you're creating a solution visually or as a vision, know the other technologies got you got to work with?
Because if you look at those type curves, none of them are looking at you.
You've got to go to them and say, you know, in order for your what's it to work this is you need our technology, and that's the only the opening the door to get in the door.
You've gotta show my demonstration of how semantic technology will enable their technology to do stuff that they had never.
They will never be able to do, and they never imagined they'd be able to do so.
Then you choose the various technologies going to partner with, and then you make your road map based on.
OK, a road map.
The analogy to the human world is you want to go from one place to another place.
Where are you going?
So I want to solve the.
I want to contribute to higher productivity in the virtual workplace or the high performance workplace.
That's the goal you want to achieve.
What technologies are you going to have to augment in order to get there?
So I'm emphasizing the importance of focusing on problem domains.
And then making a concrete case to the technology communities that, without your help, would not be able to achieve their goal either as quickly or as well.
OK.
